The Big Conn: finance in football

04/03/2014

After addressing the York Union about the beautiful game, award-winning Guardian journalist and author David Conn talks to Jamie Summers about the state of finances in English football

Image by

By undefined undefined

It is no secret that football is an ever-changing game. Over the last twenty years, the entire landscape has been revolutionised by the treasure chest of money delivered by satellite TV and the Premier League. The modern era may be far removed from the dark old days of the 1980s, marred by horrific events such as the Bradford fire in 1985, or the Hillsborough disaster in 1989; but it has been widely criticised by fans and the media alike for becoming detached from the ordinary supporter in the stands. One club to come in for severe criticism is Manchester City, who won the Premier League title in 2012 after assembling a star-studded squad, costing hundreds of millions of pounds. Award-winning Guardian journalist and Manchester City supporter David Conn is one of this country's most respected investigative sports journalists, whose latest book, Richer Than God, explores how football has been transformed by money. When David came to speak to the York Union last week, I took the opportunity to interview him. When I asked whether money has ruined football, he gave an unsurprisingly detailed response. "I think if you tried to give it a one word answer, you wouldn't be doing justice to the complexity of the story. What I say is not that money has ruined football, but the way it has been so unequally distributed and the way that they've charged supporters more to buy tickets is the problem." David studied English Literature at the University of York during the mid-1980s. The cost of matches in contrast to then is a source of frustration with the path which football has taken. "When I was at university, football just wasn't an exclusive, expensive experience. It's not that money has ruined football. In many ways it's made it so much better, but the way in which it's been turned into a business for people to exploit, that's what ought to have been regulated. The importance of supporters' wishes is an integral part of David's philosophy. In recent years, a number of clubs including Portsmouth, FC United and most notably AFC Wimbledon have become fan-owned, and he regards this as a blueprint of how the game ought to be run. "I believe in supporter-owned clubs. I believe that fundamentally, if a football club is truly a 'club', then they're membership organisations, not owned by one person or one family which has bought it. "Having become alienated from Manchester City for various reasons, I've become a supporter of the ideals, if not becoming a fan of, FC United of Manchester, because it's owned by the fans and it's a sort of rebellion against the way money has tarnished football." There is a real sense from speaking to David that he believes passionately in these ideals as being what football is really about: the game being for the fans. I was intrigued, then, to ask his opinions on owners such as Vincent Tan at Cardiff; and Assem Allam at Hull, who have made headlines for riding roughshod over the wishes of the very supporters which have sustained their clubs. "I think that they are symptoms of the fact that it's wrong for football clubs to be bought by one person," David muses. "That's what I'm trying to get across in a lot of my work; that we shouldn't really be for sale in that way. They are clubs that people have a sense of belonging to, so I feel like the changing of the colour of the kit; the changing of the name at Hull just because he can; are almost very clear symbols of the fact that the whole system of clubs being up for sale to individuals is wrong. "A lot of the problem is financial. Because clubs make losses, they rely on these kinds of people to come in, whereas if the clubs didn't make losses, they could sustain themselves." With the current state of Premier League finances seemingly as unsustainable as ever, David looks towards Germany for a more ideal model to adopt. "I've highlighted the German Bundesliga, where supporters have to own at least fifty per cent plus one share of clubs. It's looked at the Premier League example and said no, they want to remain supporter-owned clubs." And equally as far removed from the incessant hype of the Premier League and its lamentable self-obsession with money, David appreciates the enchanted simplicity of just playing the game itself; having grown up playing the game on local parks in Chorlton, Manchester, it's still the most basic form of the game which has the greatest appeal. "The game itself has got a great romance; the best thing about it is just playing it," he says, excitedly. "I've talked in the book about the let-down of the Francis Lee takeover at Manchester City, Thaksin Shinawatra, the human rights abuser of the worst kind, taking over the football club; of Sheikh Mansour being the billionaire who has bought my club. I've come through that and said, you know what, you can still go and play football at night. "I play 6-a-side with my mates. When I was younger, I loved playing and I loved watching, and when you're a child, the thrill of going to a game is better than playing on a muddy park. Now for me, playing on a muddy park is the essence of what the game is. It's a great and simple thing playing sport, and it can be really overcomplicated. It shouldn't be exploited commercially; it should be nurtured as a sport. That's the argument that I've always made." Having studied at York, participating in University sport and the social life that came with it is something which David looks back on with warm memories. "I played for the University and we had a pretty good team. We played really well, but we got to be such good mates that the drinking tended to take a bit more of a prominence than the football! I really enjoyed going to Lancaster for the Roses. There were two clubs in York; one was the Roxy and the other was Ziggy's. The York Arms near the Minster was also a really good scene." After speaking about his opinions on the game and his time here, David was also insistent that he left an important message for current students at the University: "It's nice to come back so long after I left to talk about my book and writing for the Guardian. "It was nice to have a room full of students and I want to say that I hope they have a great three years here, and that it's a rich and rewarding time for them. It's not always easy at university but I want to pass good wishes on to the students at York." Speaking to David Conn, what is clear more than anything is his passion for the game. He speaks with a real conviction and a belief that football should go back to basics, putting the ordinary supporter first. I went into his talk and interview intrigued about what he would say, and left feeling inspired. He reminds us that although football has become commercialised, it is ultimately a simple game to be enjoyed by everyone; fans are football's beating heart, and we are all stakeholders in its future. Maybe more people should take note of what he's got to say. At the time of writing, I'm only a handful of pages in, but I'd also bet that Richer Than God was well worth the tatty, screwed-up fiver that I pulled out of my wallet to pay for it.
